Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Visualization, analysis, and HPC modeling of subglacial hydrology from high-resolution 3D conduit scans acquired with a novel sensor
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will examine the processes controlling the flow of water through and beneath an Arctic glacier. The hydraulic properties of glaciers are a major factor influencing the rate at which glaciers slide on the underlying rock. Understanding subglacial flow is critical to developing models that accurately predict how glaciers will behave in response to warming climate and how glaciers will contribute to sea level rise. For outreach and educational purposes, the project will develop a web-based, interactive fluid dynamics tutorial concerning subglacial conduits. A project web site will also be developed. The project will contribute to workforce development by supporting the training of a graduate student and by providing partial support for three early-career scientists.
This study will perform three-dimensional computational fluid dynamics (CFD) large eddy simulations (LES) of turbulent flows in a subglacial conduit using realistic surfaces and mesh boundaries. The computations will be done using 3D high-performance computing. The conduit geometry and roughness will be based on a unique set of field measurements made on a Svalbard glacier using with a modified video-game controller at mm resolution. The result of this effort is a first-ever high resolution visualization of a real subglacial conduit and the first subglacial LES simulations with realistic geometry. Results will be compared with model output using the more standard Darcy-Weisbach or Manning formulations. The study will provide improved insights into hydrological processes in mountain glaciers and large ice sheets such as the Greenland Ice Sheet.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dynamic links between the hydrology of the Greenland Ice Sheet and its motion remain a key source of uncertainty in predictive models of sea level rise. During summer, meltwater is delivered to the bed of the Greenland Ice Sheet through vertical caves. Meltwater delivery increases subglacial water pressure, decreases friction between the ice and glacier bed, and causes the ice sheet to speed up. Increased ice velocities persist until conduit enlargement lowers subglacial water pressure, thereby reducing ice velocity. Limited accessibility has resulted in few direct measurements within the Greenland Ice Sheet’s subglacial drainage system. Consequently, numerical models have frequently been used to investigate the subglacial hydrology and impacts on ice motion. A persistent problem for these models, however, has been how to accurately parameterize water flow resistance in subglacial conduits. Flow resistance directly regulates subglacial water pressure, energy transfer, and ice-melting in subglacial conduits, making it an important, but poorly constrained, model parameter.

This project was the first attempt to estimate accurate and physics-based flow resistance for a real subglacial conduit. First, we used new technologies to create a high-resolution 3D map of a physically accessible conduit beneath an arctic glacier in Svalbard. We then used these 3D models in computational fluid dynamics models to map flow resistance within meter-scale segments of the conduit using simulated water flow and finally, we used the 3D model to simulate water flow and resistance along the entire length of the conduit. Results from these studies indicate that commonly used numerical models underpredict water flow resistance in subglacial conduits and therefore predict faster conduit enlargement rates, lower subglacial water pressures and slower ice velocities than are likely to occur in nature. Our results suggest additional modeling work using computational fluid dynamics models is likely to improve our understanding of the subglacial hydrological systems and their links to ice motion, which will ultimately improve predictions of rates of sea level rise.
